paper_metadata.title: Measuring the Impact of the Cocoa Livelihood Program (CLPI) on Cocoa Producer Yields in West Africa

program_information.country: Multiple: Ghana, Cote d'Ivoire, Nigeria, Cameroon
program_information.program_name_citation: This study measures the impact of the first phase of the Cocoa Livelihood Program (CLPI), a current World Cocoa Foundation project sponsored by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
program_information.country_citation: Using data collected from 2,048 pre and post CLPI interviews of cocoa producers in Ghana, Cote d'ivoire, Nigeria and Cameroon
program_information.target_population_citation: The project seeks to improve the livelihood of over 200,000 small cocoa producers in Sub-Saharan Africa

component_b_assets.assets_evidence_citation: The project seeks to improve the livelihood of over 200,000 small cocoa producers in Sub-Saharan Africa via training, crop diversification and farmer based organizations

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: The results show that yield enhancements attributable to CLPI are 36%, 38%, 49% and 24% in Ghana, CÃ´te D'Ivoire, Nigeria and Cameroon, respectively
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: Using this rich dataset and applying a difference-in-differences modeling method

bonus_information.cost_mentions: Total program cost of $158-$200 per beneficiary and estimated annual benefits of $86-$152 per beneficiary over 25 years
bonus_information.cost_evidence_citation: Using a total program cost of $158-$200 per beneficiary and estimated annual benefits of $86-$152 per beneficiary over 25 years, the benefit-cost ratios were estimated to range from $13 to $22 for every dollar spent on human capital development
